Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
April 14, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes and rules are also violations of the
Modified Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204- 6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall not
permit a child caring institution staff member to begin working
unless all of the following has been completed using the forms,
and in the manner, prescribed by the department:
(a) A criminal record check as referenced in R 400.4113(f),
including a fingerprint-based check of national crime information
databases, unless an alternative criminal history check has
been approved by the federal government.
(b) A check of Michigan's child abuse and neglect central
registry or Canadian provincial agency as referenced in R
400.4113(i).
One of seven new employee files did not have a criminal record check or a central
registry check completed prior to the employee’s start date.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
Three of seven new employee files did not have references completed prior to the
employee being hired. One of seven new employee files did not have references
that were less than 12 months old. The employee was previously employed by the
facility and was re-hired, without completing new references.
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
4

180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
One of nine employee files lacked a written performance evaluation.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is
in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCAN Contract Contractor Responsibilities – Services to be Provided –
Oct 17: 2.10.r. – Wardrobe/Personal Possessions
Page 24
The Contractor shall assure that children have an adequate
wardrobe as defined by and documented on the Clothing
Inventory Checklist (DHHS-3377) while in placement and upon
leaving placement. When the child is absent or at the conclusion
of the placement, the Contractor shall have a process in place
to keep the child's wardrobe and possessions safe until claimed
by the child or DHHS. If the possessions are not claimed within
90 calendar days, the Contractor may dispose of the items at its
discretion.
Three of three youth files did not have a completed DHHS-3377, Clothing Inventory
Checklists.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The facility has submitted six acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The facility had ten special investigations
during this period under review. The investigations involved the facility performing
unwarranted restraints, failure to report information to Centralized Intake,
documentation of medical care not being completed consistently, not following
internal policies, and not completing variable room checks. The facility’s corrective
action plan compliance is monitored quarterly, and they have completed all current
corrective action plans.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported staff turnover occurring at the houses, most recently
the supervisor at Sherk House putting in his notice. There are many employees
working at Ashmun and Sherk houses that have been employed for less than one
year. Another challenge identified was finding post placements for the youth in care.
There have been some youth placed at the houses that have been a challenge. The
Chief Administrator reported having to give a 30-day notice on a couple youth due to
the youths’ mental health needs. The management team has been providing a lot of
education to staff regarding licensing rules, policies and the “why” behind what Eagle
Village does. The facility has seen this as a positive tool for the staff. Corrective
action plans have been implemented and changes have been made as needed.
Interviews
Youth reported in interviews feeling safe, understanding the rules of the house, and
having a lot of activities available to them. One youth stated she knows the staff care
about them (kids) by the way they treat us. There were no concerns noted by any of
the youth interviewed. Staff reported many changes occurring in the house but
feeling with the newly assigned supervisor, things are now moving in a positive
direction. Staff stated they feel supported, receive regular training, and have weekly
meetings. One staff expressed concerns with how the restraint rules have changed
and how the rules will be changing again.
6

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
